title: Do people with a mental health condition have regular care review meetings?
analysis_commentary:
The term 'CPA' describes a framework introduced in 1990 to support and coordinate effective mental health care for people with mental health problems in secondary mental health services. The CPA is used to coordinate care for people who have more severe or complex mental health needs. Because their needs are generally more severe and/or complex it is likely the experience and services they get will differ from people not on CPA (Department of Health, 2008).
http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130107105354/http:/www.dh.gov.uk/prod_consum_dh/groups/dh_digitalassets/@dh/@en/documents/digitalasset/dh_083649.pdf

Here, we can see that people on a CPA are more likely to have at least one meeting to review their care in a year. In 2014, 83% of people on a CPA had a meeting to review their care, compared to 69% of people not on a CPA. The number of people having a meeting to review their care has increased markedly in the past year, from 75% to 83% for patients on a CPA, and from 53% to 69% for patients not on a CPA, both of these increases are significant.
data_source: Care Quality Commission, Community Mental Health Survey
